case_name: Municipal Corporation of Delhi v. Appellants

facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 49 of 1973 filed by special leave against Delhi High Court judgment dated August 22, 1972 in Cr. Revn. No. 93 of 1972

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 49 of 1973. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated August 22, 1972 of the Delhi High Court at New Delhi in Cr. Revn. No. 93 of 1972.

facts.text: Municipal Corporation of Delhi filed complaint on September 10, 1970 before Judicial First Class Magistrate Delhi against appellants under s.7 read with s.16 of Prevention of Food Adulteration Act for giving false warranty in respect of curry powder

anchor.surface_text: The Municipal Corporation of Delhi filed a companyplaint on September 10, 1970, before the Judicial First Class Magistrate, Delhi against the appellants under s. 7 read with s. 16 f  of the Prevention of Food Adulteration Act, 1954, hereinafter called the Act, alleging that they gave a false Waranty in respect of the curry powder manufactured by them.

facts.text: Appellants appeared in response to summons and filed application to quash proceedings on ground that complaint was incompetent, which was dismissed by Magistrate

anchor.surface_text: In response to the summons, the appellants appeared and filed an application for quashing the proceedings on the ground that the companyplaint was incompetent. The learned Magistrate dismissed the application.

facts.text: Appellants filed revision against Magistrate's order to Additional Sessions Judge, which was dismissed

anchor.surface_text: The appellants filed a revision from the order to the Additional Sessions Judge. That was dismissed.

facts.text: Appellants filed revision to Delhi High Court against Additional Sessions Judge's order, which was dismissed

anchor.surface_text: The appellants then filed a revision against that order before the High Court.The High Court also dismissed the revision.

facts.text: On November 28, 1968, Food Inspector went to shop of Ram Prakash Oberoi and found him storing curry powder for sale

anchor.surface_text: On November 28, 1968, the Food Inspector went to the shop of one Ram Prakash Oberoi and found that he was storing for sale curry powder.

facts.text: Food Inspector purchased three sealed tins of curry powder from Ram Prakash Oberoi

anchor.surface_text: The, Food Inspector purchase  three sealed tins of curry powder from him and after following the procedure enjoined by the Act,

facts.text: Food Inspector sent one sample of curry powder to Public Analyst who reported it adulterated

anchor.surface_text: sent one sample to the Public Analyst, who, after examining it, sent his report that the sample was adulterated.

facts.text: Food Inspector filed complaint against Ram Prakash Oberoi under s.16 read with s.7 of the Act

anchor.surface_text: A companyplaint Was filed against Ram Prakash Oberoi by the Food Inspector alleging that he companymitted an offence under S. 16 read with s. 7 of the Act.

facts.text: Ram Prakash Oberoi stated under s.342 that he purchased curry powder in sealed tins from appellants under warranty and sold in same condition

anchor.surface_text: Ram. Parkash Oberoi, in his statement under s. 342, stated that he had purchased the curry powder in sealed tins from the appellants under a warranty given by them and that he solo the curry powder in the same companydition in which he had purchased it from the appellants.

facts.text: First appellant gave evidence that curry powder manufactured by second appellant company and sold in tins to concern of Ram Prakash Oberoi, and admitted issuing warranty

anchor.surface_text: The first appellant was examined in the case. He gave evidence that the curry powder was manufactured by the second appellant companypany and that it had been sold in tins to the companycern of which Ram Prakash Oberoi was the proprietor. He also admitted the issue of a warranty on behalf of the second appellant.

facts.text: Ram Prakash Oberoi acquitted by Magistrate as he discharged onus under s.19(2) of the Act

anchor.surface_text: In the light of the evidence, Ram prakash Oberoi was acquitted, as, according to the Magistrate, he had discharged the onus which lay upon him in order to avail himself the defence under s. 19 2  of the Act.

facts.text: Magistrate pronounced judgment acquitting Ram Prakash Oberoi on October 25, 1969

anchor.surface_text: In the companycluding portion of the judgment which was pronounced on October 25, 1969, the Magistrate observed

facts.text: Magistrate observed that Municipal Corporation of Delhi could institute complaint against warrantor for issuing false warranty

anchor.surface_text: the Magistrate observed that it is open to the Municipal Corporation of Delhi to institute a companyplaint against the warrantor companycerned for issuing a false warranty for the. sale of adulterated curry powder to M s. T. D. Bhagwan Dass,

facts.text: Appellants contended that they ought to have been impleaded in proceedings against Ram Prakash Oberoi and tried, so present complaint barred

anchor.surface_text: The companytention of the appellants in the application before the Magistrate to quash the proceedings was that they ought to have been impleaded in the proceedings against Ram Prakash Oberoi and tried of the offence alleged to have been companymitted by them and, that number having been done, the, companyplaint was barred.

facts.text: High Court concurred with lower courts and held complaint competent, no bar due to non-impleadment under s.20A

anchor.surface_text: The High Court companycurred with the companyclusions of the, Courts below and held that the fact that the appellants were, number impleaded and tried along with Ram Prakash oberoi under s. 20A was number bar to the prosecution of the appellants for the offence of giving- false warranty and that the companyplaint was companypetent.

facts.text: Appellants submitted Food Inspector should have filed joint complaint against Ram Prakash Oberoi and appellants as he knew of warranty under s.14A

anchor.surface_text: The appellants submitted before us that it was incumbent upon the Food Inspector to have filed a joint companyplaint against Ram Prakash Oberoi and the appellants as them Food Inspector had ever opportunity to know that the appellants, had given a warranty when the articles which were found to be adulterated were  sold to Ram Prakash Oberoi.

facts.text: Appellants submitted Magistrate ought to have impleaded them under s.20A in Oberoi's case

anchor.surface_text: They also submitted that in was numberduty upon the Food Inspector to have joined the also as accused, the learned Magistrate who tried Prakash Oberoi, in any event, ought to have impleaded the appellant in that case under s. 20A of the Act and tried the appellants

facts.text: Supreme Court held no substance in appellants' contentions regarding duty to join or implead

anchor.surface_text: We do number think that there is any substance in these companytentions.

issues.text: whether it was incumbent upon the Food Inspector to have filed a joint complaint against Ram Prakash Oberoi and the appellants

anchor.surface_text: The appellants submitted before us that it was incumbent upon the Food Inspector to have filed a joint companyplaint against Ram Prakash Oberoi and the appellants as them Food Inspector had ever opportunity to know that the appellants, had given a warranty when the articles which were found to be adulterated were  sold to Ram Prakash Oberoi.

issues.text: whether the learned Magistrate who tried Prakash Oberoi ought to have impleaded the appellants under s. 20A and failure bars the present complaint

anchor.surface_text: They also submitted that in was not duty upon the Food Inspector to have joined the also as accused, the learned Magistrate who tried Prakash Oberoi, in any event, ought to have impleaded the appellant in that case under s. 20A of the Act and tried the appellants for the offence alleged to have been committed by them and that not having been done, the present companyplaint was barred.

issues.text: The further question is whether the failure of the Magistrate who tried the complaint against Ram Prakash Oberoi to implead the appellants under s. 20A of the Act and try them also along with Ram Prakash Oberoi would in any way bar the present complaint

anchor.surface_text: The further question is whether the failure of the Magistrate who tried the companyplaint against Ram Prakasi Oberoi to implead the appellants under s. 20A of the Act and try them also along with Ram Prakash Oberoi would in any way bar,the present companyplaint.

issues.text: whether although the word used in s. 20A is only may, it imports an obligation on the part of the Magistrate to implead the manufacturer, distributor or dealer

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the appellants argued that although the word used in s. 20A is only may, it imports an obligation on the part of the Magistrate to implead the manufacturer, distributor or dealer, as the- power to implead is coupled with a duty, when it appears from the evidence that the manufacturer, distributor or dealer, as the case may be, has committed an offence under the Act.

issues.text: whether the procedure in the joint trial will be more advantageous to the manufacturer, distributor or dealer than a separate trial leading to discrimination under article 14

anchor.surface_text: The appellants then contended that the, procedure in the joint trial will be more advantageous to the manufacturer, distributor or dealer, as the case may be, than a separate trial and, therefore, there could be discrimination if unguided discretion is given to an authority to choose the one or the other.

arguments.court_reasoning: No unguided discretion; s.13(2) available in separate trial if sample fit; distinguished Northern India Caterers.

arguments.claim: No provision in Act obliges Food Inspector to join warrantor/manufacturer as accused in complaint against vendor; s.19(3) assumes separate appearance possible.

anchor.surface_text: We are not aware of any provision in the Act which obliged the Food Inspector to have joined the appellants as parties to the complaint filed against Ram Prakash Oberoi. Section 20 of the Act upon which the appellants relied has nothing to do with this

arguments.claim: s.20A is enabling/discretionary provision ('may'); no mandatory obligation to implead; left to Magistrate's discretion in interest of justice.

anchor.surface_text: The further question is whether the failure of the Magistrate who tried the complaint against Ram Prakasi Oberoi to implead the appellants under s. 20A of the Act and try them also along with Ram Prakash Oberoi would in any way bar,the present complaint.

arguments.claim: Failure to implead under s.20A does not bar separate prosecution or confer immunity on manufacturer/distributor/dealer.

anchor.surface_text: Even in a case where a Magistrate could properly have impleaded the manufacturer, distributor or dealer in a proceeding against a person alleged to have committed an offence under the Act but failed to do so, that would not in any way confer an immunity

arguments.claim: Separate trial is normal rule under CrPC; joint trial exception (ss.233-239); follows precedent in State of AP v. Cheemallapati Ganeswara Rao.

anchor.surface_text: The normal rule under the Criminal Procedure Code is to try each accused separately when the offence committed by him is distinct and separate. The provisions of ss. 233 to 239 would indicate that joint trial is the exception. In State of Andhra Pradesh v.

arguments.claim: s.20A does not create exception to CrPC normal procedure requiring absolute obligation to implead; CrPC s.5(2) applies subject to special provisions.

anchor.surface_text: Section 5 (2) of the Procedure Code provides that the provisions of that Code will apply to trial of an offence under any law other than the Indian Penal Code subject to any enactment for the time being in force regulating the manner or place

arguments.claim: No prejudice in separate trial as evidence from vendor's trial not binding on manufacturer/distributor/dealer; must prove guilt afresh; acquittal/conviction of vendor not conclusive.

anchor.surface_text: There is also no likelihood of any prejudice being caused to him merely because he was not impleaded in the trial of an offence under the Act committed by any other person as, any evidence taken in that proceeding would not be binding on him

arguments.claim: Purpose of s.20A is to avoid conflicting findings; Magistrate should implead when conditions satisfied to avoid multiplicity, but failure does not bar separate prosecution.

anchor.surface_text: The real purpose of enacting S. 20A is to avoid, as far as possible, conflicting findings. If, in the prosecution instituted against the vendor, it is found that the vendor has sold the article of food in the same state as he purchased it

arguments.claim: Fact appellants not impleaded/tried with Oberoi under s.20A is no bar to prosecution for false warranty; complaint competent.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: oi under s. 20A was number bar to the prosecution of the appellants for the offence of giving- false warranty and that the companyplaint was companype

arguments.court_reasoning: Supreme Court agreed no substance in contentions.

holdings.text: There is no provision in the Act which obliged the Food Inspector to join the appellants (warrantors) as parties to the complaint filed against Ram Prakash Oberoi.

anchor.surface_text: We are not aware of any provision in the Act which obliged the Food Inspector to have joined the appellants as parties to the complaint filed against Ram Prakash Oberoi. Section 20 of the Act upon which the appellants relied has nothing to do with this matter.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No textual provision requires joining warrantor; s.20 concerns sanction for prosecution; s.19(3) assumes separate appearance possible without joining as accused.

holdings.text: Section 20A is an enabling provision using 'may'; there is nothing mandatory about impleading the manufacturer, distributor or dealer; it is discretionary based on evidence and interest of justice.

anchor.surface_text: The further question is whether the failure of the Magistrate who tried the complaint against Ram Prakasi Oberoi to implead the appellants under s. 20A of the Act and try them also along with Ram Prakash Oberoi would in any way bar,the present complaint. Section 20A provides 20A. Where at any time during the trial of any offence under this Act...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Word 'may' indicates discretion; normal CrPC rule is separate trials (ss.233-239); s.5(2) CrPC applies subject to special provisions; follows State of AP v. Cheemallapati Ganeswara Rao.

holdings.text: Failure to implead manufacturer/distributor/dealer under s.20A does not bar a separate prosecution against them or confer immunity.

anchor.surface_text: Even in a case where a Magistrate could properly have impleaded the manufacturer, distributor or dealer in a proceeding against a person alleged to have committed an offence under the Act but failed to do so, that would not in any way confer an immunity upon the manufacturer, distributor or dealer from a prosecution for any offence committed by him.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No textual bar; separate trial normal; no prejudice as prior evidence not binding; prosecution must prove guilt afresh.

holdings.text: Separate trial is the normal rule under CrPC; joint trial is exception.

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the appellants argued that although the word used in s. 20A is only may, it imports an obligation... The normal rule under the Criminal Procedure Code is to try each accused separately when the offence committed by him is distinct and separate. The provisions of ss. 233 to 239 would indicate that joint trial is the exception.

holdings.reasoning_summary: CrPC ss.233-239 prescribe separate trials as rule; precedent in State of AP v. Cheemallapati Ganeswara Rao; s.5(2) CrPC applies to PFA.

holdings.text: No violation of Article 14; no unguided discretion to choose between joint and separate trials causing discrimination; s.13(2) available in separate trial if sample fit.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants then contended that the procedure in the joint trial will be more advantageous... But, even if it is assumed that the manufacturer, distributor or dealer is also entitled to take advantage of the section and move the court to have the sample analysed by the Central Food Laboratory, we see no reason why, when he is separately tried...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Joint trial not inherently more advantageous; s.13(2) applicable separately if sample condition allows; no arbitrary choice between procedures.

holdings.text: Northern India Caterers distinguished; no unguided discretion conferred to choose more drastic procedure under s.20A.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants relied on the decision of this Court in Northern India Caterers Private Ltd. and Another v. State of Punjab and Another and contended that where two procedures are permissible, one a joint trial... The principle of the ruling has no application here.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Unlike that case, s.20A vests no unguided discretion to select between two procedures, one more prejudicial.

holdings.text: The complaint against the appellants for giving false warranty is competent; no substance in contentions to quash proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: We do not think that there is any substance in these contentions.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects all petitioner arguments; upholds lower courts; appeal by special leave dismissed implicitly.

anchor.surface_text: The further question is whether the failure of the Magistrate who tried the complaint against Ram Prakasi Oberoi to implead the appellants under s. 20A of the Act and try them also along with Ram Prakash Oberoi would in any way bar,the present complaint. Section 20A provides 20A. Where at any time during the trial of any offence under this Act...

We do number think that there is any substance in these companytentions. Section 14 provides that numbermanufacturer, article of food shall sell such article to any distributor or dealer of any vendor unless he also gives a warranty in writing in the prescribed form about the nature and quality of such article to the vendor.

Even in a case where a Magistrate could properly have impleaded the manufacturer, distributor or dealer in a proceeding against a person alleged to have committed an offence under the Act but failed to do so, that would not in any way confer an immunity upon the manufacturer, distributor or dealer from a prosecution for any offence committed by him.
